resources.string: Back again to close the app
Learn the basics of Jetpack Compose, including setting up your envionment and creating your first composable.
Dive into Compose layouts, theming, and styling your app.
Manage state effectively and navigate between screens in your Compose app.
Explore advanced Jetpack Compose topics like animations, custom layouts, and performance optimization.
Are you sure you want to reset your progress for all courses? This action cannot be undone.
The simplest way to display text is to use the <tt>Text</tt> composable.\nIt has one required parameter: the string to display.
This code will display the following text:
The <tt>Text</tt> composable has multiple optional parameters that you can use to change its content appearance.

Jetpack Compose also provides other font weights: <tt>Thin</tt>, <tt>ExtraLight</tt>, <tt>Light</tt>, <tt>Normal</tt>, <tt>Medium</tt>, <tt>SemiBold</tt>, <tt>ExtraBold</tt>, and <tt>Black</tt>.\nYou can also create custom font weight by passing an Int to the constructor.
You can add shadow to the text by creating a new <tt>TextStyle</tt> and specifying the color, offset, and blur radius of the shadow.
Draw a horizontal line over the text:
You can combine text decoration using the <tt>TextDecoration.combine</tt> function or the addition operator:

You can combine different styles in one <tt>Text</tt> using the <tt>AnnotatedString</tt> class. The helper function <tt>buildAnnotatedString</tt> allows you to easily append text fragments with different styles.

The recommended approach to displaying text is using string resources instead of hardcoding the values in code.\nThis allows for easier and less error-prone reuse of the same texts as well as preparing your app for internationalization.
You can limit the number of lines displayed for long texts:
Additionally, you can also indicate that the text is overflowing:
Jetpack Compose also provides other fonts: <tt>Default</tt>, <tt>SansSerif</tt>, <tt>Serif</tt>, and <tt>Cursive</tt>. You can also use your own custom font after importing it into the project.
To create a button, you can use the <tt>Button</tt> composable function.\nIt has two required parameters: the content to display and the callback to invoke when the user clicks the button.
To perform some action when the user clicks the button, you can pass a function to the <tt>onClick</tt> callback.
The <tt>remember</tt> and <tt>mutableIntStateOf</tt> will be explained in later lessons.
Jetpack Compose provides 5 predefined types of buttons: filled (default), tonal, outlined, elevated and text.\nYou can one which will fit your app style and its expected beahavoiur.
Another variant of button is the icon button. It ususually contains a single icon (but it can also be something different).\nIt comes in 3 variants: default, filled and outlined.

Icon buttons can also be used as toggles to cycle between checked and unchecked state on each click.\nThey have two required parameters: the current check state (boolean) and funciton to invoke when the state changes.\nIcon toggle buttons come in 3 variations: filled, tonal and outlined.
You can disable button by setting the <tt>enabled</tt>parameter to false.
You can change the colors of a button by creating new <tt>ButtonColors</tt> and passing it to the composable:
You can change the shape of a button by providing custom one.\nPadding of the content can also be specified by the <tt>contentPadding</tt> parameter.
You can add borders to button using the <tt>border</tt> parameter.\nBorder can have solid color or a gradient.
This preview requires API level 30 (Android 11) to work.
